Dynamic Innovations Wins First Place in BYDV Nationals

Leo, Giselle, Kari, Chris, and Helena were among the participants of the National Finals Comptition, representing Dynamic Innovations, as well as Los Altos High School, the LAAE, and the La Puente Valley ROP. At the National level, the team presented their creation, the Dodge Neon RO with a power point presentation, posters, a model of the car, and a rehearsed speech presentation. On Tuesday, May 23, 2005, Los Altos High School was announced as the National Champion of the 2005 BYDV Competition, bringing home a grand prize of $6, 000.

by Giselle Obregon

The Los Altos Academy of Engineering has a long-standing history of participation in the Build Your Dream Vehicle Competition. Competing since 1996, it has had a legacy of success from the competition's conception. The Los Altos Build Your Dream Vehicle teams have accumulated thousands of dollars in prizes for the program and its many projects and, in May 2005, once again brought home a trophy. However, this year was different, the BYDV team didn't bring home just any trophy--they brought home first.

In October 2004, Robert Franz, LAAE advisor, assigned Giselle Obregon, junior, to the task of forming one team that she believed could meet the challenge of the new BYDV assignment to create a car that was "so hot it could make your eyes sweat." Having one team would mean that it would be a greater concentration of truly talented students since last year, when there were three teams, dispersing the talent and ability, not one team made it to the national finals competition. Finally, a coalition of two seniors, Michael Sanora and Leonardo Micolta, five juniors, Richard Westbrook, Helena Xu, Kari Wong, Chris Liu, and Giselle Obregon, and two sophomores Ann Chong and Desiree Magat formed Dynamic Innovations 04-05.

The first task in the competition was to submit a report containing the main components of the competition- 3-D vehicular model designs, Finance, Engineering, Ergonomics and Safety, and Marketing. Out of 320 entries nation wide, Dynamic Innovations was one of the 20 teams that advanced to the semi-finals where each team was required to submit a video with

Dynamic Innovations 2004-2005 Team: (from left, top row) Leonardo Micolta, Giselle Obregon, Richard Westbrook, Michael Sanora, Chris Liu, Helena Xu. (bottom row) Kari Wong, Desiree Magat, Ann Chong.

Solar Shadow III Victorious in

Solar Bike Rayce!

by Ann Chong

On an overcast Sunday, May 22, 2005, the Los Altos Academy of Engineering participated in the 2005 Solar Bike Rayce located in Topeka, Kansas. Of the eight entries, only two cars finished, including LAAE's Solar Shadow III. LAAE placed first place in the high school division and second place overall. The race

The Los Altos Academy of Engineering Newsletter Staff:

Editor-in-Chief: Ann Chong

Staff Writers:

Helena Xu Desiree Magat

Chris Chang Giselle Obregon

was one of the closest ever seen, the first place car finished with a time of 2:39:16 and Solar Shadow III finished with a time of 2:39:17-- a mere second had determined the overall winner. At the last stretch of the race the driver, Robert Navarro had accelerated and used up what little power he had left. For long seconds the two cars, Mercury and Solar Shadow III, were neck and neck. The finish line was at the top of an incline and as soon as Solar Shadow III hit the bottom of the slope, it slowed down rapidly and the Mercury passed it up. Although LAAE did not place first overall, the students are happy and proud of their most recent accomplishment. They have once again demonstrated their talent and ingenuity in the completion and success of yet another solar vehicle and hope to build a more efficient full-size solar vehicle this year.

when completed, will be the first hydrogen fuel cell car a high school has manufactured in the United States, if not the world. The target is to complete the body by the end of November and announce the rollout date shortly thereafter. The rollout is planned to be held at the Irwindale Speedway with the presence of many prominent politicians and media coverage. LAAE's ultimate goal is to have the car completed, tested, and ready for the rollout much before the end of the school year.

This is Infusion's third year in construction and is also the year it will be definitely completed. Completing Infusion has been the main goal of the Los Altos Academy of Engineering since the school year began. LAAE plans to use Infusion as a showcase for our many projects and to attract donations and media coverage for our upcoming project, the full-size solar vehicle.

Infusion Gets Rolling!

by Chris Chang

The goal of the Los Altos Academy of Engineering this year is to complete our fuel cell car, Infusion. Infusion has encountered many difficulties along the way, but the students are happy that they will be soon announcing the completion and rollout date. Infusion,

Chris Liu and Adam Cardenas work on a fiberglass lay-up on Infusion's mold.

The Solar Boat team tests its boat in the LAHS pool.

Aaron Norris, Daniel Metchkoff, Eric Huang, Andrew Chen, Sophia Yang, Eugene Kim, Adam Cardenas, Ray Raya, Jennifer Liu, and Henry Lee. The Los Altos Academy of Engineering Solar Boat Team was one of four high schools in the district to be sponsored by

the Upper San Gabriel Municipal Water District. The Solar Cup competition was held in 2005 from May 13 through May 15 at Lake Skinner in Temecula. The team managed to finish in the top ten teams and placed sixth. This was their second year competing in Solar Cup and had been much more aggressive than last year's team since they were contending against thirty three different high schools.

On the first day, Friday May 13, 2005, the team registered, had their boat inspected, and qualified to race. The second day the team raced in the sprint heats. The third day the team competed in the endurance heats and presented their visual display. Their visual display was about filtration and deionization of water, and the display received third place.

After the competition, the team went to the Upper San Gabriel Municipal Water District office in El Monte and organized a presentation of their experiences and discoveries. The Los Altos Academy of Engineering Solar Boat team would have never been able to make this project possible, if it was not for the three thousand dollar donation from the Upper San Gabriel Water District.

The Solar Boat Team has higher expectations and hopes to do better this year since its members have more experience and now know what to do in order finish in the top three teams.

and third in the nation.

Currently, the team is training new members in programming and building as well as sharpening their own skills to get ready for the upcoming Regional Competition in March. The team plans to sweep the Regional once more with four first-place trophies, Seeding, Head-to-Head, Documentation, Overall, and place first overall at the national level.

LAAE JPL Team's Innovative Endeavor

by Aaron Mayeda

Last year the Los Altos JPL teams placed 3rd out of 27 in the JPL Annual Invention Challenge. The team consisted of 7 juniors, team leader Aaron Mayeda, Robert Navarro, Peter Xu, Eric Huang, Jeff Cui, Ben Zhou, and Justin Hsieh. The competition was to build a device that was to move a 10-lb bowling ball on top of a five foot tower, down five feet, and across 3 feet into a pan that sits on top of springs above a raw egg in the fastest time. When that ball comes to rest into the pan, the egg can not be cracked or the team is disqualified. The Los Altos team built a device that guided the ball down a ramp into a box that had a trap door on the bottom. When the ball was in the box, a sensor was tripped and a motor was activated to pull the trap door and the ball fell only an inch above the pan. This year the competition is to build a device that transfers energy in three different steps to light a match in 20 seconds. The team is very excited and is confident about placing in the top three in the preliminary competition on November 19th and then advancing to finals at JPL on December 2nd.

The JPL Invention Challenge Team: (left) Peter Xu, Eric Huang, Aaron Mayeda, Robert Navarro, Ben Zhou, Justin Hsieh, Jeff Cui

LAAE Robotics Takes Third Place in National Botball Competition

by Aaron Mayeda

The Los Altos Academy of Engineering Robotics Team consists of Aaron Mayeda, senior; Cliff Fung, senior; Clara Lee, junior; Ted Wang, sophomore; and Alexander Venturoso, sophomore. The team is split into two groups: programming and building. Mayeda and Venturoso are the builders, and Fung, Lee, and Wang handle the programming. In competitions, the groups come together, plan, build, and program the best robot for the job.

Last year, this team, along with James Liu, '05 graduate, swept the Regional Robotics Competition in San Diego with four First Place trophies: Seeding, Head-to-Head, Documentation, and Overall. In the National Competition, the team placed first in Seeding
